fields.Title of Presentation: The Impact of Fuel Reduction Treatments on Carbon and Nitrogen Mineralization Processes in a Degraded Semi-arid Ecosystem
fields.Description/Abstract:
Cheatgrass (Bromus tectorum) is an invasive plant species that contributes to degradation of native sage-steppe ecosystems by increasing fuel loads and the occurrence of wild fires, and by decreasing soil nutrients and moisture. 
Attempts to restore native sage steppe ecosystems frequently have not yielded the desired results.
Manipulative experiments that apply a variety of restoration treatments will enable a better understanding of successful restoration practices.
Impacts of land management options on soil microbial activity will feedback to native plant reestablishment, as plant-soil feedbacks drive successional trajectories in ecosystems.
The USGS (United States Geological Survey) and BLM (Bureau of Land Management) have established a manipulative field experiment that assesses how fuel load reduction treatments (i.e. grazing, herbicide applications and mowing) affect reestablishment of native vegetation.
